senses.definition: a piece of land next to or around your house where you can grow flowers, fruit, vegetables, etc., usually with a lawn (= an area of grass)

examples.x: They have a gorgeous old oak tree in their front yard.
My next-door neighbor was watering her yard.

senses.definition: an area outside a building, usually with a hard surface and a surrounding wall

examples.x: The prisoners were made to line up in the prison yard.
The children were playing in the yard at the front of the school.

senses.definition: an area of land used for a special purpose or business

examples.x: a boat yard

senses.definition: a unit for measuring length, equal to 3 feet (36 inches) or 0.9144 of a metre

examples.x: They still live within yards of each other.
a beautiful white dress with yards and yards of fabric
The accident happened less than 50 yards from his home.

senses.definition: a long piece of wood fastened to a mast that supports a sail on a boat or ship
used to say that if you allow some people a small amount of freedom or power they will see you as weak and try to take a lot more
everything, or a situation which includes everything

examples.x: When Dan cooks dinner he always goes the whole nine yards, with three courses and a choice of dessert.

senses.definition: yes
used when you are commenting on what somebody has just said

examples.x: ‘We're off to France soon.’ ‘Oh yeah? When's that?’
‘I'm going to be rich one day.’ ‘Oh yeah?’ (= I don't believe you.)

senses.definition: used to say that you do not believe what somebody has just said, disagree with it, or are not interested in it

examples.x: ‘You'll be fine.’ ‘Yeah, right.’

senses.definition: the period from 1 January to 31 December, that is 365 or 366 days, divided into 12 months

examples.x: Elections take place every year.
I lost my job earlier this year.
next/last year
She died the following year.
Three million tourists visit Yellowstone every year.
She was born in the year 1865.
The crowd was much smaller than in previous years.
In the past few years, she has become one of our top-selling authors.
The museum is open all year round (= during the whole year).

senses.definition: a period of twelve months, measured from any particular time

examples.x: It's exactly a year since I started working here.
She gave up teaching three years ago.
They got married two years later.
The autobiography could only be published 100 years after his death.
I hope to retire in two years' time.
Where do you think you will be five years from now?
Seeds can live in the soil for many years.
in the first year of their marriage
Production has declined in recent years.
His early years were spent in San Francisco.
We have high hopes for the coming year (= the next twelve months).
the pre-war/war/post-war years (= the period before/during/after the war)
I have happy memories of my years in Poland (= the time I spent there).

senses.definition: age; time of life

examples.x: He was 14 years old when it happened.
She looks young for her years.
They were both only 20 years of age.
a twenty-year-old man
He died in his sixtieth year.
She's getting on in years (= is no longer young).

senses.definition: a period of twelve months connected with a particular activity

examples.x: the tax/fiscal year
the school year

senses.definition: a level that you stay in for one year; a student at a particular level

examples.x: We started German in year seven.
She was in my year at school.
The project is the work of a group of year-seven pupils.
The first years do French.

senses.definition: a long time

examples.x: It's years since we last met.
They haven't seen each other for years and years.
That's the best movie I've seen in years.
It's the first time we've met in years.
We've had a lot of fun over the years.

senses.definition: at some time in the future

examples.x: There are certain to be more job losses further down the road.
Will this movie still be funny a few years down the road?

senses.definition: the last years of somebody’s life
a very long time

examples.x: We've known each other for donkey's years.
I met him once, but that was donkey’s years ago.
This technology has been around for donkey's.

senses.definition: a person or thing that people decide is the best in a particular field in a particular year

examples.x: He was chosen as TV personality of the year.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you will/would never do something

examples.x: I'd never have thought of that in a million years.

senses.definition: used in polite expressions to describe somebody as ‘very old’

examples.x: He was a man of advanced years.
Even at my advanced age I still know how to enjoy myself!

senses.definition: to make somebody feel or look older

examples.x: The illness put years on him.
His wife's death has put years on him.

senses.definition: the desire for new sexual experience that is thought to be felt after seven years of marriage
since a very long time ago

examples.x: I've been going there every summer since the year dot.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel or look younger

examples.x: That haircut takes years off her.
Careful make-up and styling can take years off you.

senses.definition: the time when a new century/year starts

examples.x: It was built at the turn of the century.
The team are unbeaten since the turn of the year.

senses.definition: every year for many years

examples.x: People return year after year.

senses.definition: as the years pass; each year

examples.x: Year by year their affection for each other grew stronger.

senses.definition: every year
any particular year after the birth of Christ
each year, compared with the last year

examples.x: Spending has increased year on year.
a year-on-year increase in spending

senses.definition: to shout loudly, for example because you are angry, excited, frightened or in pain

examples.x: He yelled at the other driver.

examples.cf: yell at somebody to do something
examples.x: She yelled at the child to get down from the wall.
They yelled with excitement.
She yelled out in pain.
‘Be careful!’ he yelled.
The crowd yelled encouragement at the players.
He yelled out her name.
He yelled for help.

senses.definition: having the colour of lemons or butter

examples.x: pale yellow flowers
a bright yellow waterproof jacket
Her teeth were rather yellow.
She wore a pale yellow dress.
The leaves turn yellow in November.

senses.definition: a very offensive word used to describe the light brown skin of people from some East Asian countries
easily frightened
the colour of lemons or butter

examples.x: She was dressed in yellow.
the reds and yellows of the trees
The hall is decorated in pale yellow.

senses.definition: used to answer a question and say that something is correct or true

examples.x: ‘Is this your car?’ ‘Yes, it is.’
‘Are you coming? Yes or no?’

senses.definition: used to show that you agree with what has been said

examples.x: ‘I enjoyed her latest novel.’ ‘Yes, me too.’
‘It's an excellent hotel.’ ‘Yes, but (= I don't completely agree) it's too expensive.’
In reply to his question, most of them answered yes.

senses.definition: used to disagree with something negative that somebody has just said

examples.x: ‘I've never met her before.’ ‘Yes, you have.’

senses.definition: used to agree to a request or to give permission

examples.x: ‘Dad, can I borrow the car?’ ‘Yes, but be careful.’
We're hoping that they will say yes to our proposals.

senses.definition: used to accept an offer or invitation

examples.x: ‘Would you like a drink?’ ‘Yes, please/thanks.’

senses.definition: used for asking somebody what they want

examples.x: Yes? How can I help you?

senses.definition: used for replying politely when somebody calls you

examples.x: ‘Waiter!’ ‘Yes, sir?’

senses.definition: used to show that you have just remembered something

examples.x: Where did I put the keys? Oh yes—in my pocket!

senses.definition: used to encourage somebody to continue speaking

examples.x: ‘I’m going to Paris this weekend.’ ‘Yes…’

senses.definition: used to show that you do not believe what somebody has said

examples.x: ‘Sorry I'm late—the bus didn't come.’ ‘Oh yes?’

senses.definition: used to emphasize what you have just said

examples.x: Mrs Smith has just won £2 million—yes!—£2 million!

senses.definition: used to show that you are excited or extremely pleased about something that you have done or something that has happened

examples.x: ‘They've scored another goal.’ ‘Yes!!’

senses.definition: used to show that you are impatient or annoyed about something

examples.x: ‘Hurry up—it's late.’ ‘Yes, yes—I'm coming.’

senses.definition: used when you cannot give a clear answer to a question

examples.x: ‘Are you enjoying it?’ ‘Yes and no.’

senses.definition: on the day before today

examples.x: A company spokeswoman said yesterday that no final decision had been made yet.
yesterday morning/afternoon/evening
The company yesterday announced a $40 million deal.
To think I was lying on a beach only the day before yesterday.
I can remember our wedding as if it were yesterday.
They arrived yesterday.
Where were you yesterday morning?
Figures released yesterday show 4,944 people were awaiting surgery.

senses.definition: used to say that you are not stupid enough to believe what somebody is telling you

examples.x: Oh yeah? I wasn't born yesterday, you know.

senses.definition: the day before today

examples.x: Yesterday was Sunday.
What happened at yesterday's meeting?
The events of yesterday were clearly still troubling her.
She died in the early hours of yesterday.
He threatened to resign from the coalition if no agreement was reached by yesterday.

senses.definition: the recent past

examples.x: Yesterday's students are today's employees.
All her yesterdays had vanished without a trace.

senses.definition: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen

examples.x: I haven't received a letter from him yet.
I didn't receive a letter from him yet.
‘Are you ready?’ ‘No, not yet.’
We don't yet know what really happened.
We have yet to decide what action to take (= We have not decided what action to take).

senses.definition: now; as soon as this

examples.x: Don't go yet.
We don't need to start yet.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an increase in number or amount or the number of times something happens

examples.x: snow, snow and yet more snow
yet another diet book
Prices were cut yet again (= once more, after many other times).

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is the best, longest, etc. thing of its kind made, produced, written, etc. until now/then

examples.x: the most comprehensive study yet of his music
It was the tallest building yet constructed anywhere.

senses.definition: from now until the period of time mentioned has passed

examples.x: He'll be busy for ages yet.
They won't arrive for at least two hours yet.

senses.definition: used to say that something could, might, etc. happen in the future, even though it seems unlikely

examples.x: We may win yet.
She could yet surprise us all.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an increase in the degree of something (= how bad, important, etc. it is)

examples.x: a recent and yet more improbable theory

senses.definition: until now or until a particular time in the past

examples.x: an as yet unpublished report
As yet little was known of the causes of the disease.

senses.definition: used to say that while one thing is good, another thing is even better

examples.x: You can see and, better yet, hear the effects of these changes on their website.
I wanted to make my parents proud by becoming a lawyer or, better yet, a doctor.

senses.definition: not now but probably quite soon

examples.x: I can't give you the money just yet.

senses.definition: used to comment on something that was almost successful but in fact failed
despite what has just been said

examples.x: It's a small car, yet it's surprisingly spacious.
He has a good job, and yet he never seems to have any money.

senses.definition: the total amount of crops, profits, etc. that are produced

examples.x: a high crop yield
a reduction in milk yield
This will give a yield of 10% on your investment.

senses.definition: to produce or provide something, for example a profit, result or crop

examples.x: Higher-rate deposit accounts yield good returns.
The research has yielded useful information.
These trees no longer yield fruit.
The project is expected to yield good returns in future.

senses.definition: to stop resisting something/somebody; to agree to do something that you do not want to do

examples.x: After a long siege, the town was forced to yield.
He reluctantly yielded to their demands.
I yielded to temptation and had a chocolate bar.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to win, have or take control of something that has been yours until now

examples.x: He refused to yield up his gun.
The universe is slowly yielding up its secrets.
archaeological remains which are yielding up secrets from long ago

senses.definition: to move, bend or break because of pressure

examples.x: Despite our attempts to break it, the lock would not yield.

senses.definition: to allow vehicles on a bigger road to go first

examples.x: Yield to oncoming traffic.
a yield sign

senses.definition: used as the subject or object of a verb or after a preposition to refer to the person or people being spoken or written to

examples.x: You said you knew the way.
I thought she told you.
Can I sit next to you?
I want both of you to help.
I don't think that hairstyle is you (= it doesn't suit your appearance or personality).

senses.definition: used with nouns and adjectives to speak to somebody directly

examples.x: You girls, stop talking!
You stupid idiot!

senses.definition: used for referring to people in general

examples.x: You learn a language better if you visit the country where it is spoken.
It's a friendly place—people come up to you in the street and start talking.

senses.definition: you, your family and your close friends

examples.x: I wish you and yours all the best for the year ahead!

senses.definition: having lived or existed for only a short time; not fully developed

examples.x: Young babies need to be wrapped up warmly.
a young country
Caterpillars eat the young leaves of this plant.
It's a young wine, not really up to drinking yet.
The night is still young (= it has only just started).
Small businesses, especially young ones, tend to operate on a tight budget.

senses.definition: not yet old; not as old as others

examples.x: young people
They sent many young men and women off to war.
My son's thirteen but he's young for his age (= not as developed as other boys of the same age).
I'm too young to remember much about the 1990s.
They married young (= at an early age).
My mother died young.
She looks much younger than her 39 years.
I don't know how families with young children manage to cope.
a young girl/boy/adult/person
In his younger days he played rugby for Wales.
I am the youngest of four sisters.
talented young football players
I met the young Michelle Obama at Princeton.
Her grandchildren keep her young (= keep her feeling young).

senses.definition: consisting of young people or young children; with a low average age

examples.x: They have a young family.
a young audience
This cottage would be perfect for a couple with a young family.

senses.definition: suitable or appropriate for young people

examples.x: young fashion
The clothes she wears are much too young for her.

senses.definition: used to show that you are angry or annoyed with a particular young person

examples.x: I think you owe me an apology, young lady!

senses.definition: used before or after a person’s name to show the difference between them and an older relative

examples.x: the younger Kennedy
William Pitt the younger

senses.definition: used to say that people seem to be doing something at a younger age than they used to, or that they seem younger because you are now older

examples.x: The band's fans are getting younger.
Why do police officers seem to be getting younger?

senses.definition: used when you are commenting that time is passing and that you are growing older

examples.x: We need to start thinking about our retirement. We’re not getting any younger, you know.

senses.definition: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
thinking and behaving like a young person even when you are old

examples.x: My father is 76 but he’s still young at heart.
He's over 70, but he's young at heart.

senses.definition: young people should enjoy themselves as much as possible, because they will have to work and worry later in their lives
young people considered as a group

examples.x: It's a movie that will appeal to the young.
It's a book for young and old alike.

senses.definition: young animals of a particular type or that belong to a particular mother

examples.x: a mother bird feeding her young
Young in the nest may compete for food.

senses.definition: a young person or a child

examples.x: The camp is for youngsters aged 8 to 14.

senses.definition: of or belonging to the person or people being spoken or written to

examples.x: I like your dress.
Excuse me, is this your seat?
The bank is on your right.

senses.definition: of or belonging to people in general

examples.x: Dentists advise you to have your teeth checked every six months.
In Japan you are taught great respect for your elders.

senses.definition: used to show that somebody/something is well known or often talked about

examples.x: This is your typical English pub.
You and your bright ideas!

senses.definition: used in some titles, especially those of royal people

examples.x: Your Majesty
Your Excellency

senses.definition: of or belonging to you

examples.x: Is that book yours?
Is she a friend of yours?
My hair is very fine. Yours is much thicker.

senses.definition: used at the end of a letter before signing your name

examples.x: Yours sincerely/faithfully
Sincerely Yours
Yours Truly

senses.definition: your home

examples.x: Let's go back to yours after the show.

senses.definition: you, your family and your close friends

examples.x: I wish you and yours all the best for the year ahead!

senses.definition: used when the person or people being spoken to both cause and are affected by an action

examples.x: Have you hurt yourself?
You don't seem quite yourself today (= you do not seem well or do not seem as happy as usual).
Enjoy yourselves!

senses.definition: used to emphasize the fact that the person who is being spoken to is doing something

examples.x: Do it yourself—I don't have time.
You can try it out for yourselves.
You yourself are one of the chief offenders.

senses.definition: used instead of ‘you’ in order to sound polite or formal (although some people do not consider this use to be correct)

examples.x: We sell a lot of these to people like yourself.
‘And yourself,’ he replied, ‘How are you?’

senses.definition: to act naturally

examples.x: Don't act sophisticated—just be yourself.

senses.definition: alone; without anyone else

examples.x: How long were you by yourself in the house?

senses.definition: without help

examples.x: Are you sure you did this exercise by yourself?

senses.definition: for only you to have or use; not shared

examples.x: I'm going to be away next week so you'll have the office to yourself.

senses.definition: the time of life when a person is young, especially the time before a child becomes an adult

examples.x: He had been a talented musician in his youth.
She regrets that she spent her youth travelling and not studying.
to relive/recapture your youth
He joked that being good at cards was the sign of a misspent youth (= having wasted his time when he was young).

senses.definition: the quality or state of being young

examples.x: She brings to the job a rare combination of youth and experience.
His youth gives him an advantage over the other runners.

senses.definition: young people considered as a group

examples.x: the nation’s youth
Many people think the youth of today are not taught proper standards of behaviour.
training for unemployed youth
an increase in youth unemployment
contemporary youth culture
a youth worker (= somebody who works with young people)
Youth and adults tend to see things very differently.

senses.definition: a young man

examples.x: The fight was started by a gang of youths.
